Joint Power Control and Data Size Selection for Over-the-Air Computation Aided Federated Learning

Xuming An, Rongfei Fan, Shiyuan Zuo, Han Hu, Hai Jiang, and Ning Zhang X. An, S. Zuo, and H. Hu are with the School of Information and Electronics, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, P. R. China. ({3120195381,3120210836,hhu}@bit.edu.cn). R.¬†Fan is with the School of Cyberspace Science and Technology, Beijing 100081, P. R. China. (fanrongfei@bit.edu.cn).H.¬†Jiang is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G 1H9, Canada (hai1@ualberta.ca).N.¬†Zhang is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Windsor, Windsor, ON, N9B 3P4, Canada (ning.zhang@uwindsor.ca).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as an appealing machine learning approach to deal with massive raw data generated at multiple mobile devices, which needs to aggregate the training model parameter of every mobile device at one base station (BS) iteratively. For parameter aggregating in FL, over-the-air computation is a spectrum-efficient solution, which allows all mobile devices to transmit their parameter-mapped signals concurrently to a BS. Due to heterogeneous channel fading and noise, there exists difference between the BS‚Äôs received signal and its desired signal, measured as the mean-squared error (MSE). To minimize the MSE, we propose to jointly optimize the signal amplification factors at the BS and the mobile devices as well as the data size (the number of data samples involved in local training) at every mobile device. The formulated problem is challenging to solve due to its non-convexity. To find the optimal solution, with some simplification on cost function and variable replacement, which still preserves equivalence, we transform the changed problem to be a bi-level problem equivalently. For the lower-level problem, optimal solution is found by enumerating every candidate solution from the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) condition. For the upper-level problem, the optimal solution is found by exploring its piecewise convexity. Numerical results show that our proposed method can greatly reduce the MSE and can help to improve the training performance of FL compared with benchmark methods.

Index Terms:
Over-the-air computation, federated learning, power control, data size selection.

I Introduction

In recent years, mobile devices, including smartphones and sensors, have experienced an exponential growth[1, 2]. A massive amount of data are generated from these mobile devices and promote various kinds of machine learning based applications, such as disaster warning based on digital twin, health monitoring via wearable devices, user habit learning through activities of smartphone holders, etc. [3]. Traditionally, machine learning approaches train a group of labeled data in a centralized way [4]. So mobile devices need to upload their local raw data to a central server, which may consume a large amount of wireless communication resources and cause privacy issues.

To tackle the above issues, a new distributed model training architecture is proposed, called Federated Learning (FL) [5, 6, 7, 8]. In an FL system, multiple mobile devices can collaboratively learn a common model under the coordination of a base station (BS) by iteratively exchanging model parameters between the BS and the mobile devices [9]. In each iteration, the model parameters are updated separately by every mobile device, based on the common model parameter broadcasted by the BS in last iteration and the dataset at local. Then every mobile device uploads the information of its updated model parameters to the BS, who afterwards fuses the received information and broadcasts the aggregated model parameter to every mobile device. In this process, the private raw data of each mobile device is not shared with the BS, and thus, the privacy is protected at some extent. When the BS performs data fusion, it takes a weighted sum of the information received from the mobile devices. The weight associated with a mobile device depends on its data size involved in its local training.

In FL, iterations of data exchange involve frequent multiple-access communications between mobile devices and the BS, which is spectrum- and/or energy-consuming, especially when there are a lot of mobile devices or the spectrum resources are limited. To overcome this problem, over-the-air computation can be adopted, which is able to directly calculate the summation of uploaded data that are transmitted simultaneously from multiple mobile devices to the BS [10, 11], thanks to the signal supposition property of the multiple-access channel. Over-the-air computation can achieve efficient data fusion, since uploading from multiple mobile devices happens simultaneously, and has shown great potential for not only FL but also wireless sensor network [12].

With general over-the-air computation (which may or may not work with FL), since the mobile devices‚Äô transmitted signals experience heterogenous channel fading, the superposed signal cannot be exactly identical to the desired one. Hence mean-squared error (MSE) of the aggregated signal at the BS is usually taken as the performance metric. For an over-the-air computation system supporting FL, the MSE is also proved to be highly related to the training loss[13, 14, 15], which has also been disclosed in Section VI. To combat the heterogeneous channel fading and reduce the MSE, each mobile device amplifies its signal to be transmitted, and the BS also amplifies its received signal. The amplification factor at every mobile device and the BS are usually optimized jointly to minimize the MSE [12, 16]. It is always desired that the MSE should be reduced as much as possible.

When FL is conducted by over-the-air computation, recalling that the weight associated with a mobile device depends on its data size involved in its local training, it can be seen that the MSE is a function of these mobile devices‚Äô data size. On the other hand, due to the existence of overfitting, it may not be necessary to use up all the available data samples for a general machine learning task [17]. FL is not an exception either [18]. Besides, using less data samples for local training can also help to save computation burden for every mobile device. Some literature on FL have already followed this idea [19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24]. Hence we can adjust the data size of each mobile device for local training.

Based on the above discussion, we can expect that the MSE can be further reduced by adjusting the data size of every mobile device in a proper way. Motivated by this, in this paper, we investigate an FL system supported by the over-the-air computation technique, and we jointly optimize each mobile device‚Äôs amplification factor and data size and the BS‚Äôs amplification factor, so as to minimize the MSE.

I-A Main Contributions

The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    A new perspective to reduce MSE: For an FL system supported by over-the-air computation, in addition to adjusting the amplification factors at the mobile devices and the BS, we propose to also adjust the data size of every mobile device in the local training stage, so as to further reduce the MSE. An optimization problem is formulated.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Problem transformation: In the formulated problem, the cost function is with the amplification factors of the BS and mobile devices, denoted as aùëéa and bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} for kùëòkth mobile device, and the data size of the mobile devices, denoted as SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} for kùëòkth mobile device, coupled. The cost function also involves the indicator function of SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k}. Either the coupling among aùëéa, {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\}, and {Sk}subscriptùëÜùëò\{S_{k}\} or the existence of indicator function with {Sk}subscriptùëÜùëò\{S_{k}\} makes the cost function non-convex with the data size {Sk}subscriptùëÜùëò\{S_{k}\}. To solve this challenge, we remove the indicator function from the cost function with proved equivalence and transform variable SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} to another variable Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}. With these operations, the cost function of the transformed problem is a convex function of {Œ≤k}subscriptùõΩùëò\{\beta_{k}\}, which paves the way for the optimal solving of an equivalently transformed problem in the sequel.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Two-level structure to solve the transformed problem. The transformed problem is still not jointly convex with aùëéa, {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\}, and {Œ≤k}subscriptùõΩùëò\{\beta_{k}\} because of the coupling among them. We propose to decouple them and decompose the problem into two levels. In the lower-level problem, the BS‚Äôs amplification factor aùëéa is given, and we optimize the mobile devices‚Äô amplification factors {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\} and variables {Œ≤k}subscriptùõΩùëò\{\beta_{k}\}. In the upper-level problem, the BS‚Äôs amplification factor aùëéa is optimized. Through this operation, the transformed problem is equivalent with the upper-level problem.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Deriving closed-form solution for the lower-level problem: In the lower-level problem, the cost function is jointly convex with respect to the mobile devices‚Äô amplification factors {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\} and variables {Œ≤k}subscriptùõΩùëò\{\beta_{k}\}. To find the optimal solution of the lower-level problem, we investigates the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) condition of the lower-level problem and derive closed-form solution through exhaustively exploring the candidate solutions.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Solving the upper-level problem with unclear convexity: For the upper-level problem, the convexity is unclear and hard to explore. To overcome this challenge, we discover the implicit convexity of the cost function over multiple intervals via the derived closed-form solution for the lower-level problem and show how to characterize these intervals. Accordingly, we use convex optimization techniques to find the optimal solution (i.e., the minimal MSE) in each interval, and the optimal solution of the upper-level problem can be found by comparing the minimal MSE values in all the intervals.

I-B Related Work

In general FL research (which does not adopt over-the-air computation), two major topics are on the analysis of convergence to optimal/stationary solution and the minimization of time delay to convergence. On convergence analysis, with some assumptions on the convexity and smoothness of the loss function for training, the gap to the global optimal loss function is analyzed versus the number of iterations, which is expected to converge to zero with a high convergence rate, under various configuration of step size and searching gradient [25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 19, 20, 21, 31, 32]. Specially, [19, 20, 21] assume the data size of each mobile device for local computing is adjustable. On time delay minimization, [31] proposes a hierarchical FL framework where there is one cloud server connecting multiple BS‚Äôs. The association between BS and mobile devices, together with mobile devices‚Äô CPU frequency and allocated bandwidth for data uploading, are jointly optimized. [32] optimizes mobile devices‚Äô CPU frequency, downloading and uploading date rate, and transmit power for a cell-free massive MIMO network.

For over-the-air computation research, MSE is an important metric and heterogeneous channel fading between mobile devices and the BS is the major cause to increase the MSE. To overcome the heterogenous channel fading, [12] and [16] are two pioneering works, in which the amplification factors at mobile devices and the BS are jointly optimized to minimize the MSE. In [33], the authors adopt multiple antennas to combat the channel fading between the mobile devices and the BS, and digital beamforming at every mobile device, together with the hybrid beamforming at the BS, are performed jointly to reduce the MSE.

Recently there have been some research efforts on FL systems supported by over-the-air computation technique. In [2], a multiple-band system with every band supporting the over-the-air computation is investigated. Time delay for one round of data aggregation under this setup is analyzed and is shown to outperform the system using the traditional digital orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) technique. In [34], convergence analysis is performed when there is no power control. This work shows that the FL with an over-the-air computation technique can achieve the optimal solution, when the number of enrolling mobile devices is infinite. The work in [13] performs a convergence analysis when there is power control at every mobile device. It is shown that FL with over-the-air computation technique can converge to the optimal solution, when the number of enrolling mobile devices is finite, and the converging speed is highly related to the MSE. In [35], private learning rate of every mobile device is set to combat the distortion caused by heterogeneous channel fading between every mobile device and the BS. To minimize the MSE, every mobile device‚Äôs learning rate is optimized dynamically over aggregation round in multiple-input-single-output (MISO) and multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) scenarios. In [36], with an energy consumption budget imposed on every mobile device, dynamic scheduling (which determines the group of nodes that can access the radio channel) in each round of aggregation is investigated to minimize the loss function. In [37, 15], a system aided by reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) is considered. The selection of the mobile devices, beamforming at the BS, and the phase shift of RIS‚Äôs every element in each round of iteration are optimized jointly to promote convergence by reducing the optimality gap [37] or by minimizing the MSE [15].

In summary, MSE is critical in FL systems supported by over-the-air computation technique, and in the literature, there have been research efforts on MSE reduction/minimization, by, for example, adjusting the amplification factors at the mobile devices and the BS. Different from the literature, especially [12] and [16], we propose a new dimension to minimize the MSE, i.e., in addition to adjusting the amplification factors, we propose to also adjust the data size of every mobile device in local training stage, so as to further reduce the MSE. Due to the inclusion of data size optimization, the formulated joint optimization problem is much harder to solve than problems with only amplification factor optimization. Accordingly, we develop a new method to solve our formulated joint optimization problem.

I-C Paper Organization

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Section II introduces the system model and problem formulation. Section III gives our structure to solve the problem. Sections IV and V demonstrate how the lower-level and upper-level optimization problems are solved, respectively. Section VII shows numerical results, followed by our conclusion in Section VIII.

FL is implemented in a distributed manner. It has a number of iterations. Each iteration has three rounds as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Round 1: With the most-updated parameter vector ùíòùíò\bm{w} broadcasted from the BS to every mobile device, every mobile device utilizes its local data set to generate a local gradient vector of the parameter vector;

  • ‚Ä¢

    Round 2: Every mobile device uploads its local gradient vector of parameter vector ùíòùíò\bm{w} to the BS;

  • ‚Ä¢

    Round 3: The BS aggregates the gradient vectors from every mobile device to generate a new parameter vector ùíòùíò\bm{w}.

The above procedure is repeated until the parameter vector converges or there are a sufficient number of iterations.

Take the tùë°tth iteration as an example. In Round 1, to save computation burden and reduce the MSE for gradient vector aggregation (to be explained in the sequel), not all the local data points are utilized for local updating.

The metric of MSE is usually adopted to measure the distortion between ùíõ^tsubscript^ùíõùë°\hat{\bm{z}}_{t} and ùíõtsubscriptùíõùë°\bm{z}_{t}, which can be given as

with ùîº‚Äã{‚ãÖ}ùîº‚ãÖ\mathbb{E}\{\cdot\} denoting expectation, ùîº‚Äã{‚Äñ‚àák‚Äñ2}ùîºsuperscriptnormsubscriptbold-‚àáùëò2\mathbb{E}\{||\bm{{\nabla}}_{k}||^{2}\} defined as cksubscriptùëêùëòc_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K} for the ease of presentation in the following, and ‚Ñê‚Äã(‚ãÖ)‚Ñê‚ãÖ\mathcal{I}(\cdot) defined as the indicator function. For the defined MSE in (3), the ‚Ñê‚Äã(Sk)‚ÑêsubscriptùëÜùëò\mathcal{I}(S_{k}) would be zero if Sk=0subscriptùëÜùëò0S_{k}=0 and would be one otherwise. This is because when Sk=0subscriptùëÜùëò0S_{k}=0, the kùëòkth mobile device actually does not take part in the gradient aggregation, and the associated MSE will not count the gradient aggregation distortion lead by kùëòkth mobile device.

In Round 3 for the tùë°tth iteration of FL procedure, the BS utilizes the recovered signal ùíõ^tsubscript^ùíõùë°\hat{\bm{z}}_{t}, which represents an approximation of ùíõtsubscriptùíõùë°\bm{z}_{t}, to update the parameter vector ùíòùíò\bm{w} as follows

ùíòt+1=ùíòt‚àíŒ∑‚Äãùíõ^tsubscriptùíòùë°1subscriptùíòùë°ùúÇsubscript^ùíõùë°\bm{w}_{t+1}=\bm{w}_{t}-\eta\hat{\bm{z}}_{t} (4)

where Œ∑ùúÇ\eta is a pre-defined step-size.

In the procedure of FL with over-the-air computation, the MSE as expressed in (3), which represents the distortion between ùíõ^tsubscript^ùíõùë°\hat{\bm{z}}_{t} and ùíõtsubscriptùíõùë°\bm{z}_{t}, has been proved to be highly related with the training loss[13, 14, 15], which has also been disclosed in Section VI. To suppress the training loss, as expected in every training task, the MSE should be kept as small as possible. Thus, in this paper, our target is to minimize the MSE, through optimizing the variables bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k}, SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K} and aùëéa. Accordingly, the following optimization problem is formulated.

Problem 1

III Optimal Solution Structure

Looking into Problem 1‚Äôs objective function, it is the summation of the term a2‚ÄãœÉ2superscriptùëé2superscriptùúé2a^{2}\sigma^{2} and (a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àí(Sk‚àëk=1KSk))2‚Äãck‚Äã‚Ñê‚Äã(Sk>0)superscriptùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëÜùëò2subscriptùëêùëò‚ÑêsubscriptùëÜùëò0\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\left(\frac{S_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}}\right)\right)^{2}{c_{k}{\mathcal{I}\left(S_{k}>0\right)}} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}, which are always no less than zero. Intuitively, the cost function will achieve its minimal value a2‚ÄãœÉ2superscriptùëé2superscriptùúé2a^{2}\sigma^{2} if {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\} and {Sk}subscriptùëÜùëò\{S_{k}\} are properly selected to make the term (a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àí(Sk‚àëk=1KSk))2‚Äãck‚Äã‚Ñê‚Äã(Sk>0)superscriptùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëÜùëò2subscriptùëêùëò‚ÑêsubscriptùëÜùëò0\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\left(\frac{S_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}}\right)\right)^{2}{c_{k}{\mathcal{I}\left(S_{k}>0\right)}} to be zero for every k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}, especially considering that bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} can be set separately to make a‚Äãbk‚Äãhkùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚Ñéùëòab_{k}h_{k} offset Sk‚àëk=1KSksubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëÜùëò\frac{S_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}} and SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} can be set as 0 even this offset cannot be achieved for kùëòk. However, due to the existence of upper bound of bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} defined in (5a), we cannot promise to make the above offset happen for every k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}. Moreover, we cannot always require SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} to be zero for every kùëòk such that the above offset does not succeed, because of the constraint (5c) imposed on {Sk}subscriptùëÜùëò\{S_{k}\}. In one word, Problem 1‚Äôs objective function cannot achieve its lower bound a2‚ÄãœÉ2superscriptùëé2superscriptùúé2a^{2}\sigma^{2} easily.

What is even worse, in the cost function of Problem 1, it can be also observed that: 1) there exists indicator function ‚Ñê‚Äã(Sk>0)‚ÑêsubscriptùëÜùëò0\mathcal{I}(S_{k}>0) for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}, 2) the set of {Sk}subscriptùëÜùëò\{S_{k}\} are coupled each other in the term Sk‚àëk=1KSksubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëÜùëò\frac{S_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}, 3) aùëéa and bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} are entangled for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}. For the above three listed observations, any one of them can lead to the non-convexity of Problem 1, which brings challenge into problem solving. In this sequel, we will show how to find the optimal solution of Problem 1 through simplification, transformation, decomposition, and subsequent analysis on the decomposed problems.

III-C Decomposition

The cost function of Problem 3 is a convex function of {Œ≤k}subscriptùõΩùëò\{\beta_{k}\} and {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\}. However, it is not a joint convex function of aùëéa, {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\} and {Œ≤k}subscriptùõΩùëò\{\beta_{k}\}. Thus, Problem 3 is still non-convex. In the following, we will decompose Problem 3 into two levels. In the lower level, with the variable aùëéa given, all other variables are optimized, in which case the cost function E‚Äã(a)ùê∏ùëéE(a) is achieved. In the upper level, the variable aùëéa is optimized to find the minimal E‚Äã(a)ùê∏ùëéE(a). Specifically, the lower-level optimization problem is given as

Problem 4

s.t. 0‚â§bk‚â§bkmax,‚àÄk‚ààùí¶,formulae-sequence0subscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòfor-allùëòùí¶\displaystyle\quad 0{\leq}b_{k}\leq b_{k}^{\max},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (15a)
0‚â§Œ≤k‚â§Œ≤kmax,‚àÄk‚ààùí¶,formulae-sequence0subscriptùõΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòfor-allùëòùí¶\displaystyle\quad 0{\leq}\beta_{k}\leq\beta_{k}^{\max},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (15b)

Problem 5

It can be checked Problem 5 is equivalent to Problem 3.

As a summary, Problem 1 is equivalent with Problem 2 according to Lemma 1, and Problem 2 is equivalent with Problem3 by Lemma 2. Also with the equivalence between Problem 3 and Problem 5 as just disclosed, we can claim the equivalence between Problem 1 and Problem 5. It should be also noticed that the role of Problem 4 is to return the value of Problem 5‚Äôs cost function for an input of aùëéa.

IV Optimal Solution for the Lower-Level Problem (Problem 4)

For the lower-level optimization problem, i.e., Problem 4, its cost function is a joint convex function of {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\} and {Œ≤k}subscriptùõΩùëò\{\beta_{k}\}, and its feasible solution is also convex. Hence Problem 4 is a convex optimization problem. In addition, it also satisfies Slater‚Äôs condition. In this case, Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) condition can serve as a necessary and sufficient condition of the optimal solution of Problem 4 [38]. Specifically, the KKT condition can be given as follows

‚àí2‚Äã(a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àíŒ≤k)‚Äãck+Œª‚àízk+yk=0,‚àÄk‚ààùí¶,formulae-sequence2ùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùõΩùëòsubscriptùëêùëòùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò0for-allùëòùí¶\displaystyle-2(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}){c_{k}}+\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}=0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17a)
2‚Äã(a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àíŒ≤k)‚Äãck‚Äãa‚Äãhk+Œºk‚àíŒ≥k=0,‚àÄk‚ààùí¶,formulae-sequence2ùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùõΩùëòsubscriptùëêùëòùëésubscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùúáùëòsubscriptùõæùëò0for-allùëòùí¶\displaystyle 2(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}){c_{k}}ah_{k}+\mu_{k}-\gamma_{k}=0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17b)
0‚â§Œ≤k‚â§Œ≤kmax,‚àÄk‚ààùí¶,formulae-sequence0subscriptùõΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòfor-allùëòùí¶\displaystyle 0\leq\beta_{k}\leq\beta_{k}^{\max},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17c)
0‚â§bk‚â§bkmax,‚àÄk‚ààùí¶,formulae-sequence0subscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòfor-allùëòùí¶\displaystyle 0\leq b_{k}\leq b_{k}^{\max},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17d)
‚àëk=1KŒ≤k=1,superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùõΩùëò1\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\beta_{k}=1, (17e)

zk‚â•0;yk‚â•0;Œ≥k‚â•0;Œºk‚â•0,‚àÄk‚ààùí¶formulae-sequencesubscriptùëßùëò0formulae-sequencesubscriptùë¶ùëò0formulae-sequencesubscriptùõæùëò0formulae-sequencesubscriptùúáùëò0for-allùëòùí¶\displaystyle z_{k}\geq 0;y_{k}\geq 0;\gamma_{k}\geq 0;\mu_{k}\geq 0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K} (17j)

where zksubscriptùëßùëòz_{k}, yksubscriptùë¶ùëòy_{k}, Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k}, and Œºksubscriptùúáùëò\mu_{k} are non-negative Lagrange multipliers associated with the constraints Œ≤k‚â•0subscriptùõΩùëò0\beta_{k}\geq 0, Œ≤k‚â§Œ≤maxsubscriptùõΩùëòsubscriptùõΩ\beta_{k}\leq\beta_{\max}, bk‚â•0subscriptùëèùëò0b_{k}\geq 0, and bk‚â§bkmaxsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòb_{k}\leq b_{k}^{\max}, respectively, and ŒªùúÜ\lambda is the Lagrange multiplier associated with the constraint in (17e).

IV-A Characterizing Candidate Optimal Solutions

We will first find optimal solutions of Problem 4. To achieve this, special properties of an optimal solution of Problem 4 will be analyzed based on listed KKT condition in (17). From (17a) in the KKT condition, we have

(Œª‚àízk+yk)=2‚Äãck‚Äã(a‚Äãhk‚Äãbk‚àíŒ≤k),‚àÄk‚ààùí¶.formulae-sequenceùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò2subscriptùëêùëòùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùõΩùëòfor-allùëòùí¶\left(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)=2{c_{k}}\left(ah_{k}b_{k}-\beta_{k}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (18)

Substituting the expression of 2‚Äã(a‚Äãhk‚Äãbk‚àíŒ≤k)2ùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò2\left(ah_{k}b_{k}-\beta_{k}\right) in (18) into (17b), we have

(Œª‚àízk+yk)√ó(a‚Äãhk)=(Œ≥k‚àíŒºk),‚àÄk‚ààùí¶.formulae-sequenceùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëòùëésubscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúáùëòfor-allùëòùí¶\left(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)\times(ah_{k})=\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (19)

Next, we investigate two cases: 1) Œª=0ùúÜ0\lambda=0; 2) Œª‚â†0ùúÜ0\lambda\neq 0.

IV-A1 Case with Œª=0ùúÜ0\lambda=0

When Œª=0ùúÜ0\lambda=0, equation (19) becomes

(‚àízk+yk)√ó(a‚Äãhk)=(Œ≥k‚àíŒºk),‚àÄk‚ààùí¶,formulae-sequencesubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëòùëésubscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúáùëòfor-allùëòùí¶\left(-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)\times(ah_{k})=\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (20)

which implies that the term (‚àízk+yk)subscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò\left(-z_{k}+y_{k}\right) and the term (Œ≥k‚àíŒºk)subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúáùëò\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right) should be both positive or both negative. In addition, from (17f) and (17g), it can be seen that at least one of zksubscriptùëßùëòz_{k} and yksubscriptùë¶ùëòy_{k} (which are nonnegative) should be zero. Similarly, from (17h) and (17i), at least one of Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} and Œºksubscriptùúáùëò\mu_{k} (which are nonnegative) should be zero. We have three possible scenarios as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Scenario I: (Œ≥k‚àíŒºk)>0subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúáùëò0\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right)>0. Therefore, the optimal solution does not happen in this scenario and we discard it.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Scenario II: (Œ≥k‚àíŒºk)<0subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúáùëò0\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right)<0.   • ‚Ä¢

    Scenario III: (Œ≥k‚àíŒºk)=0subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúáùëò0\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right)=0.     Œ≤k=a‚Äãhk‚Äãbk,‚àÄk‚ààùí¶,formulae-sequencesubscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùëèùëòfor-allùëòùí¶\beta_{k}=ah_{k}b_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (21)

    referred to as Candidate Solution I for Problem 4. It can be seen that when Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k} and bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} satisfies (21), the KKT condition is satisfied, and the cost function of Problem 4 achieves its minimal value a2‚ÄãœÉ2superscriptùëé2superscriptùúé2a^{2}\sigma^{2}.

IV-A2 Case with Œª‚â†0ùúÜ0\lambda\neq 0

We investigate three scenarios: (Œª‚àízk+yk)=0ùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò0(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})=0, (Œª‚àízk+yk)>0ùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò0(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})>0, and (Œª‚àízk+yk)<0ùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò0(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})<0.

    • ‚Äì

      If zk=0subscriptùëßùëò0z_{k}=0, we have (Œª+yk)=0ùúÜsubscriptùë¶ùëò0\left(\lambda+y_{k}\right)=0. Since Œª‚â†0ùúÜ0\lambda\neq 0, we have yk‚â†0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}\neq 0. From (18), we have (a‚Äãhk‚Äãbk‚àíŒ≤k)=12‚Äãck‚Äã(Œª‚àízk+yk)=0ùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò12subscriptùëêùëòùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò0\left(ah_{k}b_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)=\frac{1}{2{c_{k}}}\left(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)=0.     • ‚Äì

      If zk>0subscriptùëßùëò0z_{k}>0, we have Œ≤k=0subscriptùõΩùëò0\beta_{k}=0 according to (17f), which further implies bk=0subscriptùëèùëò0b_{k}=0 for minimizing the term (a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àíŒ≤k)2‚Äãcksuperscriptùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò2subscriptùëêùëò(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k})^{2}c_{k} in the expression of MSE. This is called Candidate Solution III for Problem 4. With bk=0subscriptùëèùëò0b_{k}=0, there is yk=0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}=0 according to (17g). Given that (Œª‚àízk+yk)‚Äãa‚Äãhk=(Œ≥k‚àíŒºk)=0ùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëòùëésubscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúáùëò0\left(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)ah_{k}=\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right)=0 in this case, and recall the fact that zk>0subscriptùëßùëò0z_{k}>0 and yk=0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}=0, there is Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0.

    Scenario with (Œª‚àízk+yk)<0ùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò0(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})<0, which indicates (Œ≥k‚àíŒºk)<0subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúáùëò0\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right)<0 according to (19).     • ‚Äì

      If zk=0subscriptùëßùëò0z_{k}=0, we discuss situations of yk=0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}=0 and yk>0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}>0, respectively.

      • *

        yk>0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}>0: In this situation, we have Œ≤k=Œ≤kmaxsubscriptùõΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max} according to (17g). With this candidate optimal solution, according to (18), (a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚àíŒ≤kmax)=(Œª‚àízk+yk)2‚Äãck<0ùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò2subscriptùëêùëò0\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\beta_{k}^{\max}\right)=\frac{(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})}{2{c_{k}}}<0. Hence there is a requirement that a‚Äãhk<Œ≤kmaxbkmaxùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòah_{k}<\frac{\beta_{k}^{\max}}{b_{k}^{\max}}, i.e., a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax<Œ≤kmaxùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}<\beta_{k}^{\max}. Moreover, the inequality (Œª‚àízk+yk)2‚Äãck<0ùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò2subscriptùëêùëò0\frac{(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})}{2{c_{k}}}<0, together with the fact that zk=0subscriptùëßùëò0z_{k}=0 and yk>0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}>0, indicate Œª<0ùúÜ0\lambda<0.

      • *

        yk=0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}=0: In this situation, Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k} can range from 0 to Œ≤kmaxsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}^{\max}. This is called Candidate Solution V for Problem 4.     • ‚Äì

      If zk>0subscriptùëßùëò0z_{k}>0, from (17f) we have Œ≤k=0subscriptùõΩùëò0\beta_{k}=0, which further implies bk=0subscriptùëèùëò0b_{k}=0 for minimizing the term (a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àíŒ≤k)2‚Äãcksuperscriptùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò2subscriptùëêùëò(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k})^{2}c_{k} in the expression of MSE.   • ‚Ä¢

    Scenario with (Œª‚àízk+yk)>0ùúÜsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò0(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})>0. If each mobile device‚Äôs associated solution (i.e., Candidate Solution II, IV, or V) is feasible, then the mobile devices‚Äô solutions form optimal solution of Problem 4; otherwise, we try Œª=0ùúÜ0\lambda=0 with Candidate Solution I.

IV-B Finding An Optimal Solution of Problem 4

We partition set ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} into two disjoint subsets, ùí¶1subscriptùí¶1\mathcal{K}_{1} and ùí¶2subscriptùí¶2\mathcal{K}_{2} such that ùí¶=ùí¶1‚à™ùí¶2ùí¶subscriptùí¶1subscriptùí¶2\mathcal{K}=\mathcal{K}_{1}\cup\mathcal{K}_{2}, ùí¶1={k|a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚â•Œ≤kmax,k‚ààùí¶}subscriptùí¶1conditional-setùëòformulae-sequenceùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòùëòùí¶\mathcal{K}_{1}=\{k|ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}\geq\beta_{k}^{\max},k\in\mathcal{K}\}, and ùí¶2={k|a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax<Œ≤kmax,k‚ààùí¶}subscriptùí¶2conditional-setùëòformulae-sequenceùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòùëòùí¶\mathcal{K}_{2}=\{k|ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}<\beta_{k}^{\max},k\in\mathcal{K}\}. Consider Œª<0ùúÜ0\lambda<0. As aforementioned, for k‚ààùí¶1ùëòsubscriptùí¶1k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}, the kùëòkth mobile device‚Äôs solution is Œ≤k=Œ≤kmaxsubscriptùõΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max} and bk=Œ≤kmaxa‚ÄãhksubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚Ñéùëòb_{k}=\frac{\beta_{k}^{\max}}{ah_{k}} (Candidate Solution II); for k‚ààùí¶2ùëòsubscriptùí¶2k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}, the kùëòkth mobile device‚Äôs solution is bk=bkmaxsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòb_{k}=b_{k}^{\max}, Œ≤k=Œ≤kmaxsubscriptùõΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max} (Candidate Solution IV) or Œ≤k‚àà(a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax,Œ≤kmax]subscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}\in\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max},\beta_{k}^{\max}\right] (Candidate Solution V). We need to verify whether or not a ŒªùúÜ\lambda exists to make all these happen.

From (18) and the facts that bk=bkmaxsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòb_{k}=b_{k}^{\max} and zk=0subscriptùëßùëò0z_{k}=0 for k‚ààùí¶2ùëòsubscriptùí¶2k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}, Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k} can be written as a function with ŒªùúÜ\lambda, which is given as

Œ≤k‚Äã(Œª)=(a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚àíŒª2‚Äãck‚àíyk2‚Äãck),‚àÄk‚ààùí¶2.formulae-sequencesubscriptùõΩùëòùúÜùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùúÜ2subscriptùëêùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò2subscriptùëêùëòfor-allùëòsubscriptùí¶2\beta_{k}(\lambda)=\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\frac{\lambda}{2{c_{k}}}-\frac{y_{k}}{2{c_{k}}}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}. (22)

According to (22) and the discussion for Candidate Solution IV and Candidate Solution V, for k‚ààùí¶2ùëòsubscriptùí¶2k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}, when Œ≤k‚àà(a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax,Œ≤kmax]subscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}\in\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max},\beta_{k}^{\max}\right], we have yk=0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}=0 and Œ≤k=(a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚àíŒª2‚Äãck)=min‚Å°((a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚àíŒª2‚Äãck),Œ≤kmax)subscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùúÜ2subscriptùëêùëòùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùúÜ2subscriptùëêùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}=\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\frac{\lambda}{2{c_{k}}}\right)=\min\left(\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\frac{\lambda}{2{c_{k}}}\right),\beta_{k}^{\max}\right); when Œ≤k=Œ≤kmaxsubscriptùõΩùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max}, we have yk‚â•0subscriptùë¶ùëò0y_{k}\geq 0 and Œ≤k=(a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚àíŒª2‚Äãck‚àíy2‚Äãck)‚â§(a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚àíŒª2‚Äãck)subscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùúÜ2subscriptùëêùëòùë¶2subscriptùëêùëòùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùúÜ2subscriptùëêùëò\beta_{k}=\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\frac{\lambda}{2{c_{k}}}-\frac{y}{2{c_{k}}}\right)\leq\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\frac{\lambda}{2{c_{k}}}\right), and thus, Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k} can also be written as Œ≤k=min‚Å°((a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚àíŒª2‚Äãck),Œ≤kmax)subscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùúÜ2subscriptùëêùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}=\min\left(\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\frac{\lambda}{2{c_{k}}}\right),\beta_{k}^{\max}\right). In summary, the expression of Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k} with ŒªùúÜ\lambda can be simplified to be

Œ≤k‚Äã(Œª)=min‚Å°((a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚àíŒª2‚Äãck),Œ≤kmax),‚àÄk‚ààùí¶2,formulae-sequencesubscriptùõΩùëòùúÜùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùúÜ2subscriptùëêùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòfor-allùëòsubscriptùí¶2\beta_{k}(\lambda)=\min\left(\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\frac{\lambda}{2{c_{k}}}\right),\beta_{k}^{\max}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}, (23)

which is a non-increasing function with ŒªùúÜ\lambda.

Substituting (23) in equality (13), we can get

‚àëk‚ààùí¶1Œ≤kmax+‚àëk‚ààùí¶2Œ≤k‚Äã(Œª)=1.subscriptùëòsubscriptùí¶1superscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòsubscriptùëòsubscriptùí¶2subscriptùõΩùëòùúÜ1\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}}\beta_{k}^{\max}+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}}\beta_{k}(\lambda)=1. (24)

For equality (24), it can be found that every term on its left-hand side is a non-increasing function with ŒªùúÜ\lambda. Hence the solution, denoted Œª‚àósuperscriptùúÜ\lambda^{*}, for the equation in (24) can be found through a bisection search method for Œª‚àà(Œªmin,0)ùúÜsubscriptùúÜ0\lambda\in\left(\lambda_{\min},0\right), where

Œªmin‚âúmink‚ààùí¶22‚Äãck‚Äã(a‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax‚àíŒ≤kmax)‚âúsubscriptùúÜsubscriptùëòsubscriptùí¶22subscriptùëêùëòùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò\lambda_{\min}\triangleq\mathop{\min}\limits_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}}\quad 2{c_{k}}\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\beta_{k}^{\max}\right) (25)

Then, the optimal Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k} for k‚ààùí¶2ùëòsubscriptùí¶2k\in\mathcal{K}_{2} can be calculated according to (23).

The above solution of bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} and Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k} for the kùëòkth mobile device (also solution of Problem 4) is under the condition that (24) has a solution of ŒªùúÜ\lambda. However, when (24) does not have a solution of ŒªùúÜ\lambda, we need to find optimal solution of Problem 4 from Candidate Solution I, as follows.

Equality (24) does not have a solution of ŒªùúÜ\lambda when one of the following two events happens: 1) ‚àëk‚ààùí¶1Œ≤kmax>1subscriptùëòsubscriptùí¶1superscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò1\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}}\beta_{k}^{\max}>1; 2) ‚àëk‚ààùí¶1Œ≤kmax<1subscriptùëòsubscriptùí¶1superscriptsubscriptùõΩùëò1\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}}\beta_{k}^{\max}<1 but there does not exist a Œª‚àà(Œªmin,0)ùúÜsubscriptùúÜ0\lambda\in\left(\lambda_{\min},0\right) to make the equality (24) hold.

V Optimal Solution for Upper-Level Problem (Problem 5)

In this section, the optimal aùëéa of Problem 5, which is also optimal for Problem 2, is to be found. However, the convexity of E‚Äã(a)ùê∏ùëéE(a), which is the cost function of Problem 5, is unclear and hard to explore. This challenge will be overcome by our proposed solution given in the following.

As the value of aùëéa grows, it can be checked that the set ùí¶1subscriptùí¶1\mathcal{K}_{1} enlarges and the set ùí¶2subscriptùí¶2\mathcal{K}_{2} shrinks. Hence both set ùí¶1subscriptùí¶1\mathcal{K}_{1} and set ùí¶2subscriptùí¶2\mathcal{K}_{2} are functions of aùëéa, which are denoted as ùí¶1‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶1ùëé\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) and ùí¶2‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶2ùëé\mathcal{K}_{2}(a), respectively, in this section. Similarly the Œª‚àósuperscriptùúÜ\lambda^{*} solving the equation in (24) is also a function of aùëéa, which is denoted as Œª‚àó‚Äã(a)superscriptùúÜùëé\lambda^{*}(a) in this section.

As aùëéa grows, the cardinality of ùí¶1‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶1ùëé\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) will enlarge from 0 to KùêæK, while the cardinality of ùí¶2‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶2ùëé\mathcal{K}_{2}(a) will shrink from KùêæK to 0 at the same time. Then there would be multiple intervals of aùëéa. When aùëéa varies within any interval, the cardinality of the set ùí¶1‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶1ùëé\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) and ùí¶2‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶2ùëé\mathcal{K}_{2}(a) keep unchanged. When aùëéa grows from one interval to the next interval, the cardinality of the set ùí¶1‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶1ùëé\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) and ùí¶2‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶2ùëé\mathcal{K}_{2}(a) will change. To characterizing these intervals, the boundaries of every interval of aùëéa need to be found.

Thus, for the kùëòkth mobile device, the function F‚Äã(a)ùêπùëéF(a) and the line (Œ≤kmax‚àía‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax)superscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚Ñéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëò\left(\beta_{k}^{\max}-ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}\right) may have no intersection (when F‚Äã(a)ùêπùëéF(a) is always above (Œ≤kmax‚àía‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax)superscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚Ñéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëò\left(\beta_{k}^{\max}-ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}\right)), one intersection (when (Œ≤kmax‚àía‚Äãhk‚Äãbkmax)superscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòùëésubscript‚Ñéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëò\left(\beta_{k}^{\max}-ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}\right) is tangent with F‚Äã(a)ùêπùëéF(a) at some point), two intersections, which corresponds to one, two, and three sub-intervals such that the kùëòkth mobile device is always in ùí¶2I‚Äã(a)superscriptsubscriptùí¶2Iùëé\mathcal{K}_{2}^{\text{I}}(a) or always in ùí¶2II‚Äã(a)superscriptsubscriptùí¶2IIùëé\mathcal{K}_{2}^{\text{II}}(a). So interval ‚Ñ¨msubscript‚Ñ¨ùëö\mathcal{B}_{m} can be divided into at most 2‚Äã(K‚àím)+12ùêæùëö12(K-m)+1 sub-intervals such that when aùëéa is in one sub-interval, the set ùí¶2I‚Äã(a)superscriptsubscriptùí¶2Iùëé\mathcal{K}_{2}^{\text{I}}(a) and set ùí¶2II‚Äã(a)superscriptsubscriptùí¶2IIùëé\mathcal{K}_{2}^{\text{II}}(a) keep unchanged. The 2‚Äã(K‚àím)+12ùêæùëö12(K-m)+1 sub-intervals is calculated in such a way: For each mobile device belonging to the set ùí¶2subscriptùí¶2\mathcal{K}_{2}, there are at most two intersections. For a total number of K‚àímùêæùëöK-m mobile devices, there are at most 2‚Äã(K‚àím)2ùêæùëö2\left(K-m\right) intersections, which could divide the region ‚Ñ¨msubscript‚Ñ¨ùëö\mathcal{B}_{m} into 2‚Äã(K‚àím)+12ùêæùëö12(K-m)+1 sub-intervals. Thus, in each sub-interval of ‚Ñ¨msubscript‚Ñ¨ùëö\mathcal{B}_{m}, the cost function of Problem 5, i.e., E‚Äã(a)ùê∏ùëéE(a) in (29), is a convex function with aùëéa, and the optimal aùëéa in the sub-interval can be found by a Golden search method.

Then the optimal value of aùëéa for a‚ààùíúmùëésubscriptùíúùëöa\in\mathcal{A}_{m} (m=0,1,‚Ä¶,Mùëö01‚Ä¶ùëÄm=0,1,...,M) can be found accordingly. Then the optimal value of aùëéa for a‚àà(0,‚àû)ùëé0a\in(0,\infty) can be found by comparing the minimal cost function in intervals ùíú0subscriptùíú0\mathcal{A}_{0}, ùíú1subscriptùíú1\mathcal{A}_{1},‚Ä¶ ùíúM+1subscriptùíúùëÄ1\mathcal{A}_{M+1}.

Complexity Analysis: To find the optimal value of aùëéa, the major computation complexity is on the Golden search method for every sub-interval of ‚Ñ¨msubscript‚Ñ¨ùëö\mathcal{B}_{m} (m=0,1,‚Ä¶,Mùëö01‚Ä¶ùëÄm=0,1,...,M), with total worst-case complexity being O‚Äã(K2)ùëÇsuperscriptùêæ2O(K^{2}) for all sub-intervals of ‚Ñ¨0,‚Ñ¨1,‚Ä¶,‚Ñ¨Msubscript‚Ñ¨0subscript‚Ñ¨1‚Ä¶subscript‚Ñ¨ùëÄ\mathcal{B}_{0},\mathcal{B}_{1},...,\mathcal{B}_{M}.

VI Convergence and Optimality for Training

In terms of convergence and optimality, [15, 13, 14] have already investigated this topic for a general over-the-air computation aided FL system. According to their results, our proposed method can achieve convergence or even zero optimality gap, under some mild conditions. It is worth mentioning that the derived optimality gap is highly related to the MSE of aggregation, which also necessities MSE minimization as we do in this paper.

To be specific, for a non-convex loss function being LùêøL-smooth (whose definition can be found in [15, 13, 14]), which is applicable for the training of a neural network, the associated results on convergence or optimality gap in [15, 13, 14] are given as follows:

  1. 1.

    [15] investigates an intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRS) enhanced over-the-air computation aided FL system, which also applies for our considered system since the IRS system can also realize any channel gain between mobile devices and the BS assumed in this paper. With a general setup of signal amplification factors at both mobile devices and the BS, the average norm of the cost function‚Äôs gradient over TùëáT iterations is upper bounded as

    1T‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1ùîº‚Äã{‚à•‚àáf‚Äã(ùíòt)‚à•2}‚â§O‚Äã(1T2‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1ùîº‚Äã{‚à•Œµt‚à•2})+O‚Äã(1T‚Äã(f‚Äã(ùíò0)‚àíf‚àó)),1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìsubscriptùíòùë°2ùëÇ1superscriptùëá2superscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÄùë°2ùëÇ1ùëáùëìsubscriptùíò0superscriptùëì\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\nabla f(\bm{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\leq O\left({\frac{1}{T^{2}}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}}\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\varepsilon_{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\right)+O\left(\frac{1}{T}\left(f\left(\bm{w}_{0}\right)-f^{*}\right)\right), (32)

    where ŒµtsubscriptùúÄùë°\varepsilon_{t} denotes the aggregation error, ùîº‚Äã{‚à•Œµt‚à•2}ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÄùë°2\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\varepsilon_{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\} is the MSE of aggregation at the t‚àílimit-fromùë°t-th round of iteration, ùíò0subscriptùíò0\bm{w}_{0} and ùíòtsubscriptùíòùë°\bm{w}_{t} represent the global parameter vector at the beginning of training and the t‚àílimit-fromùë°t-th round of iteration respectively, f‚àósuperscriptùëìf^{*} is the minimal achievable value of the loss function f‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëì‚ãÖf(\cdot). It can be observed that for a fixed TùëáT, the averaged norm of loss function‚Äôs gradient is highly related to the MSE of aggregation in each step of iteration. Moreover, as T‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëáT\rightarrow\infty, the averaged norm of loss functions‚Äôs gradient trends to be zero. This verifies the convergence of our proposed method.

  2. 2.

    With œÑùúè\tau-Polyak-≈Åojasiewicz condition (whose definition can be found in [13, 14]), according to [13, 14], the optimality gap can be written as

    ùîº‚Äã{f‚Äã(ùíòT)}‚àíf‚àó‚â§O‚Äã(1T‚Äãùîº‚Äã{‚à•Œµt‚à•2})+O‚Äã(1T‚Äã(f‚Äã(ùíò0)‚àíf‚àó))+1T‚ÄãW,ùîºùëìsubscriptùíòùëásuperscriptùëìùëÇ1ùëáùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÄùë°2ùëÇ1ùëáùëìsubscriptùíò0superscriptùëì1ùëáùëä\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\{f\left(\bm{w}_{T}\right)\}-f^{*}\leq O\left({\frac{1}{T}}\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\varepsilon_{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\right)+O\left({\frac{1}{T}}\left(f\left(\bm{w}_{0}\right)-f^{*}\right)\right)+{\frac{1}{T}}W, (33)

    where WùëäW is a constant item related to system parameters such as the LùêøL, œÑùúè\tau, and the upper bound of local gradient‚Äôs variance. This result can verify not only the convergence but also the ability of achieving zero optimality gap for our proposed method.

VII Numerical Results

In this section, numerical results are presented to evaluate the performance of our proposed method. Default system settings are given as follows. There are K=20ùêæ20K=20 mobile devices in the FL system [26]. The Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k} for k=1,2,‚Ä¶,Kùëò12‚Ä¶ùêæk=1,2,...,K are randomly generated to be 3979, 3974, 3985, 3933, 4026, 3984, 3972, 3961, 3991, 3986, 4051, 3972, 3921, 3991, 3983, 3937, 3958, 4058, 4033, and 4051, respectively. cksubscriptùëêùëòc_{k} is selected to be 1 for ‚àÄk‚ààùí¶for-allùëòùí¶\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T} is selected to be 400004000040000.

We compare the performance of our proposed method with the AirFedSGD method [40], the Transmission Power Control (referred to as the TPC method in the sequel) in [16], and the Computation Optimal Policy (referred to as the COP method in the sequel) in [12]. The AirFedSGD method is the traditional FedSGD method [5] adapted to the environment of over-the-air computation, which sets the signal amplification factor bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} to be inversely proportional to the channel gain for every mobile device k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}. The amplification factor of the received signal at the BS aùëéa is simply set as 1|ùí¶|1ùí¶\frac{1}{\left\lvert\mathcal{K}\right\rvert}. The TPC method follows the idea of AirFedSGD but considers the case that the channel condition may be poor. In this case, the associated signal amplification factor has to be very high by following AirFedSGD method but cannot be achieved due to the limit of mobile device‚Äôs transmit power. The TPC method regulates the signal amplification factor to be at its maximal transmit power level for this case. The amplification factor of the received signal at the BS aùëéa is further optimized so as to minimize the aggregation MSE, which generates a closed-form solution. The COP method optimizes the signal amplification factor bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K} and the amplification factor of the received signal at the BS aùëéa jointly to minimize the aggregation MSE. For the above three methods, they all select SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} as Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}.

For ease of comparison with the AirFedSGD, the TPC, and the COP method, we also adopt their parameter setup [12, 16] of œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}, hksubscript‚Ñéùëòh_{k}, and bkmaxsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòb_{k}^{\max} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K} as follows: œÉ2=1superscriptùúé21\sigma^{2}=1; the channel coefficient hksubscript‚Ñéùëòh_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K} are i.i.d Rayleigh distributed random variables with mean being h¬Ø=œÄ/(4‚àíœÄ)¬Ø‚Ñéùúã4ùúã\bar{h}=\sqrt{{\pi}/{\left(4-\pi\right)}} (this implies a variance being 1); bkmaxsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòb_{k}^{\max} is set as 1010\sqrt{10} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}. The code to realize our numerical results is available at https://github.com/anxuming/FedAirComp.git.

VII-A MSE Improvement

Fig. 4, Fig. 4, Fig. 4, and Fig. 4 plot the MSE versus various system parameters for our proposed method, the AirFedSGD method, the TPC method, and the COP method. It can be seen that our proposed method can always achieve an MSE no larger than the one under the COP method. Moreover, the COP method also achieves a lower MSE than the ones under the AirFedSGD method and the TPC method. These results demonstrates the effectiveness of our proposed method. The reason behind can be explained as follows. Our proposed method minimizes the MSE through optimizing one more dimension of variable SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}, while the COP method simply sets SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} as Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}. Compared with the COP method, both the AirFedSGD method and the TPC method offer a sub optimal solution for minimizing the MSE also with SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} being set as Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}. Hence they achieve higher MSE than the COP method. Since the AirFedSGD method and the TPC method are always inferior to the COP method, we will mainly analyze the performance of our proposed method and the COP method in the following.

Fig. 4 shows the MSE versus the minimal required data amount STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T} for our proposed method, the AirFedSGD method, the TPC method, and the COP method. In the COP method, each mobile device utilizes all its data in its local training, and thus, its MSE does not change with STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T}. In our proposed method, the MSE increases as STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T} grows. This is because the growing STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T} means that the feasible region of Problem 2 shrinks, and thus, its cost function (i.e., the MSE) increases. When ST=‚àëk=1KDKsubscriptùëÜùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùê∑ùêæS_{T}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{D_{K}}, the MSE of our proposed method and the COP method are the same. This is because, to satisfy ST=‚àëk=1KDKsubscriptùëÜùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùê∑ùêæS_{T}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{D_{K}}, each mobile device in our proposed method has to use all its data in its local training.

Fig. 4 shows the MSE versus the number of mobile devices KùêæK. When a number of KùêæK mobile devices are investigated, we select the first KùêæK mobile devices from the set of 20 mobile devices described at the beginning of this section. From Fig. 4, it can be seen that the MSE under the CoP method first goes down with KùêæK and then increase after K=17ùêæ17K=17. The reason is as follows. When the number of mobile devices increases, Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k} of the kùëòkth mobile device tends to decrease (recalling that the summation of Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k}‚Äôs is equal to one). Thus, the kùëòkth mobile device can have a smaller term (a‚Äãhk‚Äãbk‚àíŒ≤k)2superscriptùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò2(ah_{k}b_{k}-\beta_{k})^{2} in the expression of MSE, leading to a decreasing trend of MSE. On the other hand, the increase of the number of mobile devices means that there are more terms (a‚Äãhk‚Äãbk‚àíŒ≤k)2superscriptùëésubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò2(ah_{k}b_{k}-\beta_{k})^{2} in the expression of MSE, leading to an increasing trend of MSE. When KùêæK is smaller than 17, the decreasing trend dominates. When KùêæK increases beyond 17, the increasing trend dominates.

From Fig. 4, it can also be seen that the MSE under our proposed method decreases as KùêæK grows. The reason is as follows. Define the optimal solution of bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} and Œ≤ksubscriptùõΩùëò\beta_{k} as bkKsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùêæb_{k}^{K} and Œ≤kKsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòùêæ\beta_{k}^{K} for k=1,2,‚Ä¶,Kùëò12‚Ä¶ùêæk=1,2,...,K, respectively, when solving Problem 4 with KùêæK mobile devices. Accordingly, the minimal cost function of Problem 4, i.e., the minimal MSE with given aùëéa, can be expressed as EK‚Äã(a)subscriptùê∏ùêæùëéE_{K}(a). Then for any aùëéa, we have

EK‚Äã(a)=subscriptùê∏ùêæùëéabsent\displaystyle E_{K}(a)= ‚àëk=1K(a‚ÄãbkK‚Äãhk‚àíŒ≤kK)2‚Äãck+a2‚ÄãœÉ2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptùëésuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùêæsubscript‚ÑéùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëòùêæ2subscriptùëêùëòsuperscriptùëé2superscriptùúé2\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(ab_{k}^{K}h_{k}-\beta_{k}^{K}\right)^{2}c_{k}+a^{2}\sigma^{2} (34)

Then for the upper-level problem, i.e., Problem 5, denoting the optimal solution of aùëéa as aKsubscriptùëéùêæa_{K} with KùêæK mobile devices, we have

EK‚Äã(aK)‚â•EK+1‚Äã(aK)‚â•EK+1‚Äã(aK+1),subscriptùê∏ùêæsubscriptùëéùêæsubscriptùê∏ùêæ1subscriptùëéùêæsubscriptùê∏ùêæ1subscriptùëéùêæ1\displaystyle E_{K}(a_{K})\geq E_{K+1}(a_{K})\geq E_{K+1}(a_{K+1}),

which means that the MSE decreases as KùêæK grows for our proposed method.

In Fig. 4, the MSE is plotted versus the mean of channel coefficient h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\bar{h}. It can be observed that the MSE decreases with h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\bar{h} for all the methods. This can be explained as follows. With the increase of h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\bar{h}, hksubscript‚Ñéùëòh_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K} tends to be larger, and thus, more mobile devices are included in set ùí¶1subscriptùí¶1\mathcal{K}_{1}, and fewer mobile devices are included in set ùí¶2subscriptùí¶2\mathcal{K}_{2}. So in our cost function ‚àëk=1K(a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àíŒ≤k)2+a2‚ÄãœÉ2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò2superscriptùëé2superscriptùúé2\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)^{2}+a^{2}\sigma^{2}, we will have more terms of (a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àíŒ≤k)2superscriptùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò2\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)^{2} equal to zero (recalling that (a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àíŒ≤k)2=0superscriptùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò20\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)^{2}=0 for k‚ààùí¶1ùëòsubscriptùí¶1k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}). For the terms of (a‚Äãbk‚Äãhk‚àíŒ≤k)2superscriptùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscript‚ÑéùëòsubscriptùõΩùëò2\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)^{2} for k‚ààùí¶2ùëòsubscriptùí¶2k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}, although they cannot be equal to be zero, they have a higher chance to get a smaller value thanks to the increase of hksubscript‚Ñéùëòh_{k}. Thus, the MSE of our proposed method decreases. Due to a similar reason, the MSE of the COP method also decreases, recalling the fact that the COP method is actually to solve our Problem 2 by setting SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} as Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}.

In Fig. 4, the MSE is plotted versus the variance of noise œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}. It can be seen that the MSE increases as œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2} grows for both our proposed method and the COP method. For our proposed method, the reason can be explained as follows. Define the cost function of Problem 2 as E‚Äã(a,{bk},{Sk},œÉ2)ùê∏ùëésubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptùúé2E\left(a,\{b_{k}\},\{S_{k}\},\sigma^{2}\right), and the optimal solution of aùëéa, {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\}, and {Sk}subscriptùëÜùëò\{S_{k}\} for solving Problem 2 (when the variance of noise is œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}) are given as a‚àó‚Äã(œÉ2)superscriptùëésuperscriptùúé2a^{*}(\sigma^{2}), {bk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ2)}superscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptùúé2\{b_{k}^{*}(\sigma^{2})\}, and {Sk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ2)}superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptùúé2\{S_{k}^{*}(\sigma^{2})\}, respectively. Then the minimal achievable cost function of Problem 2 can be written as E‚Äã(a‚àó‚Äã(œÉ2),{bk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ2)},{Sk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ2)},œÉ2)ùê∏superscriptùëésuperscriptùúé2superscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptùúé2superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptùúé2superscriptùúé2E\left(a^{*}(\sigma^{2}),\{b_{k}^{*}(\sigma^{2})\},\{S_{k}^{*}(\sigma^{2})\},\sigma^{2}\right). For œÉ12<œÉ22superscriptsubscriptùúé12superscriptsubscriptùúé22\sigma_{1}^{2}<\sigma_{2}^{2}, we have

E‚Äã(a‚àó‚Äã(œÉ12),{bk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ12)},{Sk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ12)},œÉ12)‚â§E‚Äã(a‚àó‚Äã(œÉ22),{bk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ22)},{Sk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ22)},œÉ12)‚â§E‚Äã(a‚àó‚Äã(œÉ22),{bk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ22)},{Sk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ22)},œÉ22)ùê∏superscriptùëésuperscriptsubscriptùúé12superscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúé12superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúé12superscriptsubscriptùúé12ùê∏superscriptùëésuperscriptsubscriptùúé22superscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúé22superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúé22superscriptsubscriptùúé12ùê∏superscriptùëésuperscriptsubscriptùúé22superscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúé22superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúé22superscriptsubscriptùúé22\begin{split}&E\left(a^{*}(\sigma_{1}^{2}),\{b_{k}^{*}(\sigma_{1}^{2})\},\{S_{k}^{*}(\sigma_{1}^{2})\},\sigma_{1}^{2}\right)\\ \leq&E\left(a^{*}(\sigma_{2}^{2}),\{b_{k}^{*}(\sigma_{2}^{2})\},\{S_{k}^{*}(\sigma_{2}^{2})\},\sigma_{1}^{2}\right)\\ \leq&E\left(a^{*}(\sigma_{2}^{2}),\{b_{k}^{*}(\sigma_{2}^{2})\},\{S_{k}^{*}(\sigma_{2}^{2})\},\sigma_{2}^{2}\right)\end{split} (35)

in which the second inequality is because E‚Äã(a‚àó‚Äã(œÉ2),{bk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ2)},{Sk‚àó‚Äã(œÉ2)},œÉ2)ùê∏superscriptùëésuperscriptùúé2superscriptsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptùúé2superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëòsuperscriptùúé2superscriptùúé2E\left(a^{*}(\sigma^{2}),\{b_{k}^{*}(\sigma^{2})\},\{S_{k}^{*}(\sigma^{2})\},\sigma^{2}\right) is an increasing function of œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}. As of the curve for the COP method, it can be explained in the same way.

VII-B Training Performance Improvement

In this sub-section, the performance of training a neural network ResNet-18 through our proposed method is analyzed and compared with benchmark methods.

Fig. 6 and Fig. 6 present the performance of training ResNet-18 based on CIFAR10 dataset by utilizing our proposed method and benchmark methods. It can be observed that our proposed method trends to outperform the benchmark methods as the communication round TùëáT grows, in terms of not only test accuracy but also training loss. This verifies that our effort on reducing the MSE for gradient aggregation can help to improve training performance.

In Fig. 8 and Fig. 8, the performance comparison for training ResNet-18 is evaluated on another dataset CIFAR100. Results similar to Fig. 6 and 6 can be also obtained. This strengthens the meaningfulness of our efforts on reducing the MSE for gradient aggregation.

Define (bkmax)2/œÉ2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëò2superscriptùúé2{\left(b_{k}^{\max}\right)^{2}}/{\sigma^{2}} as the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}, in Fig. 10 and Fig. 10, we plot how the test accuracy varies with the SNR for our proposed method, under CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets respectively. As a comparison, the performance of the traditional FedSGD method [5], which is noise free for aggregation, is also plotted. From Fig. 10 and Fig. 10, it can be observed that as the SNR goes up, the test accuracy of our proposed method trends to increase and approaches to the performance of the FedSGD method. These results offer such an inspiration for improving the test accuracy of our proposed method: We can increase bkmaxsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòb_{k}^{\max} for k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K} to overcome the negative effect of additive noise for aggregation to achieve a similar performance like the noise free aggregation method, such as the FedSGD.

In Fig. 12 and Fig. 12, by utilizing our proposed method, the test accuracy and training loss for training ResNet-18 under dataset CIFAR100 are plotted versus STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T}, respectively. It can be seen that as STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T} grows, the performance of both test accuracy and training loss will first improve and then degrade. The reason can be explained as follows. When STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T} first grows, larger set of involving data samples is beneficial for improving the training performance. As STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T} further increases, the negative effect of overfitting shows up, which leads to the degradation of training performance. This result implies that it would not be optimal to use up all the available data samples, which backs up our operation on adjusting the data size for training. Moreover, this result also suggests us to choose a proper STsubscriptùëÜùëáS_{T} value in real application.

VIII Conclusion and Further Discussion

In this work, we have exploited data size selection for multiple mobile devices in a FL system powered by over-the-air computation. The amplification factor at the mobile devices and the BS and the data sizes of the mobile devices are optimized jointly to minimize the MSE. To solve the problem optimally, which is non-convex due to the coupling of multiple categories of variables and the existence of indicator function, we first simplify the cost function while preserving equivalence and perform variable transformation, and then solve the transformed problem in a two-level structure. Computation complexity of our proposed method is also analyzed, which is shown to be polynomial even in the worst case. Numerical results illustrate that our proposed method can help to further reduce MSE and improve convergence performance compared with benchmark methods. Our research results could provide helpful insights for the application of a FL system supported by over-the-air computation technique in the future. Moreover, recalling that the over-the-air computation technique can be also utilized for fusing the sensed data from multiple wireless sensors, our proposed method in this paper can be also extended to such a scenario. Specifically, when the mean value of some environmental parameter is to be estimated from a number of random observations at multiple wireless sensors, the number of random observations at each wireless sensor adopted for fusion, associated with the amplification factor at the wireless sensors and the fusion center, can be adjusted to minimize the data fusion MSE with the help of our proposed method as well.

which holds since the defined Œû~~Œû\tilde{\Xi} in (40) satisfies Œû~‚â•Œ≤~kDk~Œûsubscript~ùõΩùëòsubscriptùê∑ùëò\tilde{\Xi}\geq\frac{\tilde{\beta}_{k}}{D_{k}} for ‚àÄk‚ààùí¶for-allùëòùí¶\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Additionally, it can be also found that

‚àëk=1KS~k=‚àëk=1KŒ≤~kŒû~=1Œû~‚â•ST.superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript~ùëÜùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscript~ùõΩùëò~Œû1~ŒûsubscriptùëÜùëá\sum_{k=1}^{K}\tilde{S}_{k}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\tilde{\beta}_{k}}{\tilde{\Xi}}=\frac{1}{\tilde{\Xi}}\geq S_{T}. (43)

According to (42) and (43), we can claim that a set of {S~k}subscript~ùëÜùëò\{\tilde{S}_{k}\} satisfying (39a) and (39b) has been mapped from the set of {Œ≤k~}~subscriptùõΩùëò\{\tilde{\beta_{k}}\} satisfying (12) and (13).

This completes the proof.

Appendix C Proof of Lemma 3

In case that the set ùí¶1‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶1ùëé\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) and the set ùí¶2‚Äã(a)subscriptùí¶2ùëé\mathcal{K}_{2}(a) keep unchanged, it can be checked that the function P‚Äã(a,x)ùëÉùëéùë•P(a,x) is non-decreasing with both aùëéa and xùë•x. Hence for Problem 6, as aùëéa grows, the feasible region of xùë•x will not shrink (or will enlarge), which will lead to the nonincrease of its minimal cost function, i.e., F‚Äã(a)ùêπùëéF(a).

This completes the proof.
